title: Million-Pound Deals in England and Wales Soared 12-Fold in 20 Years
text:
A home sale over £1 million, once extremely rare in England and Wales, now accounts for nearly one out of every 50 transactions in the two countries, according to new research from mortgage firm Private Finance.



In 2018, England and Wales registered 15,445 deals for £1 million (US$1.29 million) or more, a 12-fold increase compared to two decades ago when little more than 1,250 deals of that magnitude were recorded in 1999, according to the research published Wednesday morning British time.

Private Finance analyzed two decades worth of official residential transaction data recorded by the British government to look at how the luxury market has grown.



The explosion of million- and multi-million-pound house sales highlights how drastically home prices have inflated in the span of 20 years and how a general lack of affordability is causing overall home sales to decline.



The total number of home sales across all price points in England and Wales was fewer than 870,000 in 2018, almost one-third less than in 1999, according to Private Finance.



But even as overall sales declined, deals of £5 million or more were dramatically increasing during that time. There were a paltry 22 sales of that scale in 1999, compared to 323 last year, an increase of 1,368%, government data showed.



“The housing market has undergone a radical transformation, with average house prices in particular almost unrecognizable,” said Simon Checkley, managing director at Private Finance. “Transactions of houses in higher price brackets have soared in accordance with rising prices, creating a much bigger and more complex prime market.”

The explosion in luxury home sales is notable even when inflation is stripped away. For instance, a £1 million home today would have cost roughly £590,000 in 1999. But sales of that scale accounted for less than 0.5% of the market, compared to nearly 2% today.



A look at the past five years also puts the luxury slowdown in some perspective. Even as prices in London and England’s South East slowed, luxury deals of £1 million or more grew every year until a downtick in 2018.
